Authors:
Johannes Alwyn van der Linde, Diana L Six, Z. Wilhelm de
Beer, Michael J. Wingfield, Jolanda Roux
Title:
Novel ophiostomatalean fungi from galleries of Cyrtogenius
africus (Scolytinae) infesting dying Euphorbia ingens
Keywords:
Ophiostoma, Ophiostomataceae, ophiostomatalean fungi,
Ophiostomatales, Scolytinae
Abstract:
Euphorbia ingens trees have been dying in large numbers in
the Limpopo Province of South Africa for approximately 15 years. The
ambrosia beetle Cyrtogenius africus is often found infesting diseased
and dying trees. The aim of this study was to identify the
ophiostomatoid fungi occurring in the galleries of C. africus. Logs
infested with this beetle were collected from the KwaZulu-Natal,
Limpopo, Mpumalanga, and North West Provinces of South Africa. Fungi
belonging to the Ophiostomatales were identified based on morphology and
comparison of sequence data for the Î²-tubulin, ITS1-5.8S-ITS2 and LSU
gene regions. A novel species of Ophiostoma and a novel genus in the
Ophiostomatales were identified. Inoculation studies with these fungi
produced lesions in the branches of healthy E. ingens trees.
